items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  8.02
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Proposed Annual Update to the Local Control Accountability Plan (LCAP)
		 
The text below was taken directly from the State approved LCAP template.
		 
The Local Control Accountability Plan (LCAP) and annual update template shall be used to provide details regarding local educational agencies’ (LEAs) actions and expenditures to support pupil outcomes and overall performance pursuant to Education Code sections 52060, 52066, 47605, 47605.5, and 47606.5.
		 
For school districts, pursuant to Education Code section 52060, the LCAP must describe, for the school district and each school within the district, goals and specific actions to achieve those goals for all pupils and each subgroup of pupils identified in Education Code section 52052, including pupils with disabilities, for each of the state priorities and any locally identified priorities.
		 
The LCAP is intended to be a comprehensive planning tool. LEAs may reference and describe actions and expenditures in other plans and funded by a variety of other fund sources when detailing goals, actions, and expenditures related to the state and local priorities. LCAPs must be consistent with school plans submitted pursuant to Education Code section 64001. The information contained in the LCAP, or annual update, may be supplemented by information contained in other plans (including the LEA plan pursuant to Section 1112 of Subpart 1 of Part A of Title I of Public Law 107-110) that are incorporated or referenced as relevant in this document. 
		 
For each section of the template, LEAs should comply with instructions and use the guiding questions as prompts (but not limits) for completing the information as required by statute.
		 
State Priorities
The State priorities listed in Education Code sections 52060 and 52066 can be categorized as specified below for planning purposes, however, school districts and county offices of education must address each of the state priorities in their LCAP.
		 
A. Conditions of Learning:
		 
Basic: degree to which teachers are appropriately assigned pursuant to Education Code section 44258.9, and fully credentialed in the subject areas and for the pupils they are teaching; pupils have access to standards-aligned instructional materials pursuant to Education Code section 60119; and school facilities are maintained in good repair pursuant to Education Code section 17002(d). (Priority 1)
		 
Implementation of State Standards: implementation of academic content and performance standards adopted by the state board for all pupils, including English learners. (Priority 2)
		 
Course access: pupil enrollment in a broad course of study that includes all of the subject areas described in Education Code section 51210 and subdivisions (a) to (i), inclusive, of Section 51220, as applicable. (Priority 7)
		 
Expelled pupils (for county offices of education only): coordination of instruction of expelled pupils pursuant to Education Code section 48926.  (Priority 9)
		 
Foster youth (for county offices of education only): coordination of services, including working with the county child welfare agency to share information, responding to the needs of the juvenile court system, and ensuring transfer of health and education records.  (Priority 10)
		 
B. Pupil Outcomes:
		 
Pupil achievement: performance on standardized tests, score on Academic Performance Index, share of pupils that are college and career ready, share of English learners that become English proficient, English learner reclassification rate, share of pupils that pass Advanced Placement exams with 3 or higher, share of pupils determined prepared for college by the Early Assessment Program. (Priority 4)
		 
Other pupil outcomes: pupil outcomes in the subject areas described in Education Code section 51210 and subdivisions (a) to (i), inclusive, of Education Code section 51220, as applicable. (Priority 8)  
		 
C. Engagement:
		 
Parent involvement: efforts to seek parent input in decision making, promotion of parent participation in programs for unduplicated pupils and special need subgroups.  (Priority 3)
		 
Pupil engagement: school attendance rates, chronic absenteeism rates, middle school dropout rates, high school dropout rates, high school graduations rates. (Priority 5)
		 
School climate: pupil suspension rates, pupil expulsion rates, other local measures including surveys of pupils, parents and teachers on the sense of safety and school connectedness. (Priority 6)
		 
In addition to the strategic planning engagement stakeholder and focus group meetings, the District has had many community engagement meetings to specifically discuss the LCFF and LCAP.  The following are the dates of the community engagement meetings:
		 
February, 2015
Student Forums—February 3rd and 10th 
Migrant Education Parent Meeting—February 6th 
		 
March, 2015
Budget Advisory Committee—March 11th
DAC/DELAC Meeting—March 17th 
                
April, 2015
Vietnamese Parents Meeting—April 25th 
		 
May, 2015
Update to the Board on the community input—May 14th 
School site input—School Site Council and English Learner Advisory Committee 
June, 2015
Public Hearing at Regular Board Meeting—June 9th 
Board of Trustees Approval (Board Meeting)—June 18th   
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the proposed annual update to the Local Control Accountability Plan (LCAP).

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Custodial Staffing Increases Effective Fiscal Year 2015-16
	 
On February 12, 2015, the Board received the Custodial Services Operational Efficiency Study report developed by Prismatic Services.  The report included thirteen recommendations, twelve of which have been implemented or are in process.  In order to implement the final recommendation, District administration is proposing to address custodial staffing inequities and the inadequacy of custodial staffing effective fiscal year 2015-16, by increasing custodial staffing by 5.625 FTE as follows:

The District has put 1.0 FTE on the preliminary budget; therefore, 4.625 is the being requested to add to the budget
	 
Notes
(1) District administration is proposing no decrease in staffing, despite Prismatic's recommendation.  The current custodial staffing level provides the required programmatic coverage fro duration of operating hours, coverage for absences, and tasks requiring more than one person.
	 
(2) Prismatic's recommendation is based on school cleaning standards, which is more labor intensive than a professional office environmental like the Education Center.  The current custodial staffing of 2 FTE is adequate.

$347,896.00

General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve an increase of 4.625 FTE custodian positions effective fiscal year 2015-16.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item: 8.04
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:  
						 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Approve and Adopt the Proposed Budget for Fiscal Year 2015-16
		 
The 2015-16 Annual Budget reflects the actions and input of the Governing Board, Superintendent, stakeholders, and staff to develop a budget that is responsive to District needs and priorities.  The final budget was prepared taking into account all changes relative to the Governor’s May Revision proposal. 
		 
The District may consider submitting a 45-day budget revision to the adopted budget depending upon the results of the State’s final budget adoption actions.  The District will still need to be vigilant in managing deficit spending and will need to closely monitor future spending to ensure spending is balanced. The District will continue to closely monitor and report on the State’s budget circumstances and how it impacts the District as information becomes available.         
		 
The 2015-16 budget indicates that the District is recommending that a positive budget be adopted based on the District’s ability to maintain sufficient reserves for the upcoming and two subsequent fiscal years. The attached budget book with executive summary provides a more detailed analysis of the fiscal year 2015-16 District budget and required State Standardized Account Code Structure (SACS) Reporting Forms.  
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the annual budget for fiscal year 2015-16 with a positive certification for the 2015-16 fiscal year and two subsequent years.

Item:  8.05
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, Randy Phelps, Director of Information Technology Services, André Bell, Assistant Director of Capital Accounting and Purchasing, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Award an Agreement for Construction of the Distictwide Security Cameras Upgrade Project
	 
The Board approved a Districtwide Security Cameras Upgrade project, whose focus is the installation of a districtwide, enterprise level, IP-based camera solution to improve safety, create a single system with excellent resolution and border to border coverage.
	 
Through extensive field investigations during the design of the project, TCG discovered deficiencies in the network backbone, bandwidth and wireless capacity upon which the cameras are to operate, which needed to be remedied. Because of the symbiotic relationship between the camera and network projects and because of TCG’s technical expertise in both, TCG included the necessary network expansion scope in the plans and specifications for this project.
	 
The completed plans and specifications were issued to prequalified construction contractors.  On May 27, 2015, three bids were received, as follows:
G4S Technology LLC       $7,554,269.00
Johnson Controls, Inc.      $8,487,183.89
Intermountain Electric       $8,864,915.00
The bids were analyzed for responsiveness and responsibility.  The low bid submitted by G4S Technology LLC was found to be responsive and responsible, and of fair market value.
	 
In order to award the construction contract, the project budget requires an augmentation, as follows:

FISCAL IMPACT:
Project budget augmentation:  $4,310,000
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees augment the project by $4,310,000, and award an agreement in the amount of $7,554,269 to G4S Technology LLC for construction of the Districtwide Security Cameras Upgrade project, and execute change orders in accordance with Board Policy 3312.1.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Board Members’ Compensation/Adjustments to Compensation per Education Code §35120
	 
	 
The calculation of Board Members’ monthly compensation is governed by Education Code section 35120.  Currently, Board Members’ monthly stipend as allowed by law is $441.00.  On June 19, 2014, the Board took action to increase its monthly compensation from $420.00 to the current amount of $441.00. 
	 
Education Code section 35120(e) provides:
	 
“On an annual basis, the governing board may increase the compensation of individual board members beyond the limits delineated in this section, in an amount not to exceed 5 percent based on the present monthly rate of compensation. Any increase made pursuant to this section shall be effective upon approval by the governing board.”
	 
Administration recommends that the Board approve a 5% increase to the Board Member compensation to take effect July 1, 2015, resulting in a new monthly compensation per Board Member of $463.05 pursuant to Education Code section 35120(e).
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Twenty-one dollars ($22.05) more per Board Member in monthly compensation
                                                                                              
FUNDING SOURCE:
Unrestricted General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board approve a 5% increase in Board Member monthly compensation to $463.05 per month, effective July 1, 2015, pursuant to Education Code section 35120(e).

Item:  12.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services, and Jennifer Klassen, Coordinator of Student Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Santa Clara County Office of Education / East Side Union High School District’s Plan for Expelled Youth
	 
	 
As mandated by Education Code 48926, each county superintendent of schools in counties that operate community schools pursuant to Section 1980, in conjunction with superintendents of the school districts within the county, shall develop a plan for providing education services to all expelled students in that county.  The plan shall be adopted by the governing board of each school district within the county and by the county board of education.
	 
The plan shall enumerate existing education alternatives for expelled students, identify gaps in educational services to expelled students, and strategies for filling those service gaps.  The plan shall also identify alternative placements for students who are expelled and placed in district community day school programs, but who fail to meet the terms and conditions of their rehabilitation plan or who pose a danger to other district students, as determined by the governing board.
	 
Each county superintendent of schools, in conjunction with the superintendents of the school districts, shall submit to the Superintendent of Public Instruction the county plan for providing educational services to all expelled students in the county no later than June 30, 2015, and shall submit a triennial update to the plan to the Superintendent of Public Instruction, including the outcome data pursuant to Section 48916.1, on June 30th thereafter.
	 
Per Education Code 48916.1, at the time an expulsion of a student is ordered, the governing board of the school district shall ensure that an educational program is provided to the student who is subject to the expulsion order for the period of the expulsion.  Except for students expelled pursuant to subdivision (d) of Section 48915 (related to the five (5) offenses mandatory for recommendation of expulsion/to expel), the governing board is required to implement the provisions of this section only to the extent funds are appropriated for this purpose in the annual Budget Act or other legislation, or both.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the Santa Clara County Office of Education/East Side Union High School District's Plan for Expelled Youth.

TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Karen Poon, Director of Finance, and Nadia Davis, Attendance Accounting Manager
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Foreign Exchange Student Program   
	 
	 
The Business Services Division in collaboration with Educational Services, has explored the viability of offering a foreign exchange program at East Side Union High School District.  The implementation of a foreign exchange program at East Side will provide foreign students an opportunity to be introduced to our culturally diverse community, or rich program offerings, and the opportunity to learn in the technology capital of the world "Silicon Valley."  We believe all of these factors make East Side a very viable and competitive option to the more costly private schools.  The objectives of our program would be to provide foreign exchange students educational enrichment which will promote a better understanding between American students and students of other countries, improve declining enrollment, and bring additional revenue into the District. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Revenue totaling over $3.5 million over 3 years
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Tuition
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the development of a foreign exchange program at East Side Union High School District as detailed in the Board presentation with regard to next steps and budget authorization.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  13.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Karen Poon, Director of Finance, and Kelly Kwong, Senior Manager of Internal Controls
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Authorize IPACE (Independent Parent Action CommitteE), a School Connected Organization, to Solicit Contributions or Funds per Education Code 51520(a) and 51521 for the Speech and Debate Club at Evergreen Valley High School
	 
	 
A School Connected Organization (“SCO”) is a separately organized and controlled non-profit entity that raises funds for student programs.  SCOs are frequently organized and known as “booster” clubs and parent/teacher/student associations.  SCO are not controlled by or overseen by the District.  The law requires, however, that SCO must obtain District approval to solicit funds on the District's school sites for the benefit of students, or if it solicits funds on the representation that the money received is to be used in whole or in part for the benefit of students or any other District school or students.
	 
Education Code section 51520(a) provides: 
“During school hours, and within one hour before the time of opening and within one hour after the time of closing of school, pupils of the public school shall not be solicited on school premises by teachers or others to subscribe or contribute to the funds of, to become members of, or to work for, any organization not directly under the control of the school authorities, unless the organization is a nonpartisan, charitable organization organized for charitable purposes by an act of Congress or under the laws of the state, the purpose of the solicitation is nonpartisan and charitable, and the solicitation has been approved by the county board of education or by the governing board of the school district in which the school is located.” (Emphasis added.)
	 
Education Code section 51521 further provides in part: 
“No person shall solicit any other person to contribute to any fund or to purchase any item of personal property, upon the representation that the money received is to be used wholly or in part for the benefit of any public school or the student body of any public school, unless such person obtains the prior written approval of either the governing board of the school district in which such solicitation is to be made or the governing board of the school district having jurisdiction over the school or student body represented to be benefited by such solicitation, or the designee of either of such boards.”
	 
In addition, Board Policy 1230 School Connected Organizations states, “Persons proposing to establish a school-connected organization shall submit a request to the Governing Board for authorization to operate at the school… Requests for subsequent authorization shall be presented to the Superintendent or designee annually…”
	 
After a review of IPACE financials and other criteria, the Administration recommends that the Board authorize IPACE to solicit contributions or funds on any District site for the benefit of any District students or programs. 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize IPACE, a School Connected Organization, pursuant to Education Code 51520(a) and 51521 to solicit contributions or funds on any District site for nonpartisan and charitable purposes for the benefit of District students or programs.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators
	 
	 
The Commission on Teacher Credentialing issues a permit to an individual who qualifies for an emergency credential based on the Board approved annual Declaration of Need.  This applies to the following credentials or authorizations: Emergency CLAD, BCLAD, Resource Specialist, Library Media, Clinical or Rehabilitative Permits.
	Every attempt is made to hire highly qualified credentialed teachers before considering people with an emergency permit. 
	Attached is the Commission on Teacher Credentialing form titled Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators.  Pursuant to the direction from the county office of education's credentials office, the district is over estimating the number of permits it might require in order to cover any unanticipated needs that might occur during the course of the 2015-2016 school year.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
As per salary schedule
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General and Special Education funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators.

Attached for the Board's review is the proposed classified, classified management and certificated administrative holiday schedule for the 2015-2016 school calendar.
	 
CSEA, Chapter 187, on behalf of classified employees, and the District have reached a tentative agreement on the holiday schedule and are requesting final approval from the Board of Trustees.  The proposed holiday schedule includes the contractual holidays, plus three additional paid holidays during Christmas Break.  It also includes two days during the leave where employees will have the option of charging annual leave, floating holiday, compensatory time or leave without pay.  This arrangement will enable the District to shutdown all operations during the two-week break, which will result in savings in utility costs.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Various

As per salary schedule

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Award Site and Facilities Lease Agreements for Independence High School Interior Demolition of Building B (Project No. Z-065-601) and Campus Improvements (Project No. Z-065-602) Lease Leaseback Projects with McCarthy Building Companies, Inc.
	 
On June 19, 2014, the Board awarded a Preconstruction Agreement to McCarthy Building Companies, Inc. (McCarthy) to be the Lease Leaseback Developer for the Independence High School Modernization of Building B and Campus Site Improvement Projects (Item 15.03).
	 
Upon approval of the Preconstruction Agreement, McCarthy immediately began implementing components of their Agreement including reviewing the project plans and specifications prepared by Cody Anderson Architects (CAW) for constructability, technical review, value engineering, and obtaining pricing from subcontractors and suppliers to generate a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP).
	 
As part of the thorough constructability and technical review of the plans and specifications, McCarthy provided information for potential conflicts in the plans and specifications that could lead to requests for information and potential change orders during the course of construction.  Van Pelt Construction Services (VPCS), the project’s Construction Manager, conducted multiple meetings with McCarthy and CAW to review and address McCarthy’s comments. CAW incorporated relevant comments into the final backcheck set of plans and specifications under review by Division of the State Architect (DSA).
	 
During the review of the plans and specifications, McCarthy identified multiple value engineering options to ensure project costs remain within budget. Facilities staff, VPCS and CAW evaluated the options.  CAW incorporated the accepted value engineering options into their final design, which is reflected in McCarthy’s Building B demolition and Campus Site Improvements GMP. 
	 
The plans and specifications for the Modernization of Building B are under review by DSA.  While these plans are under review, McCarthy can commence with the interior demolition of Building B in order to be ready for construction upon DSA approval of plans.  Staff plans to seek Board approval of an amendment to the Site and Facilities Lease Agreements at a future Board meeting, following DSA approval, to include the Building B reconstruction cost to the GMP.
	 
To develop the GMP, McCarthy divided the plans and specifications into work categories (WC) or subcontractor trade areas.  McCarthy solicited multiple subcontractors to provide bids for each WC, including firms from the District’s prequalified list of contractors.  McCarthy interviewed the two lowest bid subcontractors for each WC to ensure that their bids contain the full scope and meet the experience and qualification criteria required by the contract documents. McCarthy provided their subcontractor pricing data used to prepare the GMP.
	 
Additionally, in developing the GMP, McCarthy prepared a detailed list of assumptions and clarifications.  Each of these assumptions and clarifications were reviewed and accepted by Facilities staff, CAW and VPCS.  
	 
Through this process of reviewing of the plans and specification for constructability and technical review issues, generating value engineering options and preparing the list of assumptions and clarifications, McCarthy developed their list of Owner contingency items.  This list was reviewed and edited by Facilities staff, VPCS and CAW.  As agreed by McCarthy, the Owner’s Contingency can only be used for a limited list of unforeseen conditions. McCarthy accepts the majority of design risk and unforeseen conditions associated with design conflicts.  McCarthy’s GMP reflects this acceptance of risk. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Measure I - $920,330.00
Fund 67 -    $394,427.00
Not to Exceed $1, 314,757.00
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Obligation Bond Measure I and Fund 67
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees award Site and Facilities Lease Agreements with McCarthy Building Companies, Inc., for the Interior Demolition of Building B (Project No. Z-065-601) and Campus Improvements (Project No. Z-065-602) Lease Leaseback Projects, in an amount not to exceed $1,314,757.00.

SUBJECT:

The attached lists the Bond/Capital Projects Contracts for Professional Services at or below $50,000 being recommended for Board ratification. 
					 
Fiscal Impact:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Funding Source:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services at or below $50,000 as recommended in the attachment and authorization is being requested for the Superintendent and/or designee to execute amendments to the Agreement that may be needed during the term, provided such amendments do not: (i) extend the term of the contract; (ii) increase the price of goods or services provided under the contract by the greater of ten percent (10%) of the contract amount (based on the original contract amount exclusive of any approved amendments in the aggregate); or (iii) alter the quality or quantity of services or goods provided under the Board-approved contract per Board Policy 3312.1.
